bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, October 22, 1923

div1.p: Connor reports to Carter that the Mexican yellow fever campaign is going well, although he has had difficulties with local officials. He agrees that Maracaibo, rather than the larger Colombian towns, is the focal point for yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, October 22, 1923

TAMPICO, TAMAULIPAS
Tampico Tamps. Mexico
Octuber 22nd. 1923
Dear Doctor Carter;
div1.p:
I have delayed answering your letter of September
5th. until concluding a survey of the East Coast region. This has
been completed and have reported to Doctor Russell that no evi-
dence of yellow fever could be found, after December 1922, in the
area from the Rio Grande to Yucatan.

This year, as you probably know, there have been com-
petent Mexican physicians stationed in the principal towns and
cities for the sole purpose of making a study of the diseases
movement and to be observers in the hospitals, sanatoriums as well
as consulting with the local physicians. This effort has been well
worth while giving the Departamento de Salubridad and ourselves a
better knowledge of actual existing conditions more especially for
localities where no anti-larvae measures had been apllied and where
there was a possibility that the infection could have smouldered,
the city of Monterrey for instance.

In Merida and Veracruz we have fortified our-selves
by having a physician in each city who had recently received train-
ing in yellow fever pathology under Doctor Noguchi. In January
Doctor Ayuse will receive a fellowship from the Board for a similiar
course, upon his return to Tampico we will have the Gulf well
supplied with trained physicians who will be of great aid to the
local ‘medices’ when it comes to studying suspected yellow fever
cases.

Your suggestion of the Maracaibo district rather than the Bucaramanga-
Cucucta district is a logical one and to me it aids in clearing a previous
doubt as to the infection existing in the latter district over a term of years
either unrecognized or ignored. It worried me for a time to understand how the
infection could remain smouldering for a long time in or near cities as large as
Bucaramange or Cucuta even though the authorities tried to conceal it, they could
conceal isolated and long interval cases but an epidemic forces acknowledgement
as even the layman can diagnose classical cases. Now if we include in our perspec-
tive the Maracaibo district I can understand the infection existing for a long
time unrecognized or ignored until it reached a large city with a good supply
of non-immunes to work on when an ‘explosion’ is bound to occur. This is seeming-
ly what happened in Columbia.

I knew that Doctor Guitera had reported finding y.f. at Core in 1917,
as I had been selected to go Venezuela in the event arrangements were made but
that Government decided to handle the situation with its own personnel.

What you say relative to secondary occuring in Huigra is true from all
that I could learn from the records in Eucador and the same appears to be true
Mexico City and the plateau.

I am glad that you approve of my stressing the absence of “sporadic”
yellow fever. Many physicians in Mexico still cling to the telluric poison theory
as the cause of this infection but there is increasing evidence that our work
has convinced many that the disease can be eradicated by anti-larvae measures directed
against the aedes aegypti. Further, the medical men are coming around to depend upon
the laboratory to aid them in making a diagnosis in doubtful cases. I regard this
latter change of view-point on the part of the older physicians as a real achieve-
ment resulting from our work and will be of great service to us in the coming year
where it is quite certain that cases of y.f. will announced.

As you know most of the physicans practicing in the gulf region have
-3-
been graduated from the Mexico City Medical School and where until recently there
were few or no facilities for the study of tropical diseases. These men had been
trained to regard a show of blood from the mouth or nose accompanied by
fever and vomiting as either yellow fever or paludismo hemmorragca, for instance
I was called yesterday to see a case that had been announced as yellow fever based
unpon the presence of fresh blood in the sputum. A careful examination of the
patient revealed a lobar pneumonia.

You will be interested to know that the soap in lejia continues to
give good results in destroying aedes aegypti larvae before the stage of pupation
and is quite successful as a mosquito repellent. Some Inspectors have reported un-
favorably upon this measure but I have been able in these cases to discover
that the fault lay with the man and not the soap, some were placing a piece of
soap in the lejia and it immediately settled to the bottom of the container where
carefullyit became covered by the ashes which prevented it from dissolving or else they were
not using enough soap for the quanitity of lejia to be treated.

Here in Tampico we have decided upon the following method: ten drops
of concentrated liquid soap to the average small container or a teaspoonful of powdered
soap or flakes or rub the soap between the hands latering immersing them in the
lejia.

I have found that the use of soap in lejia permits us to reduce our
field personnel nearly 50% that is the ayudante are no longer employed as their
principal function was to carry oil used in mosquito-proofing lejias.

I hope that you have fully recovered and are now enjoying your usual
good oft expressed wish to see Mexico free of yellow fever appears to be realized.

With very good wishes to Miss Laura and the kindliest personal regards
for yourself, I remain,
div1.closer: sincerely yous, M E Connor. Dr. H.R. Carter.
